There are two vaccines that help protect individuals against hepatitis A: the hepatitis A vaccine and the hepatitis A and B combination vaccine. The hepatitis A vaccine protects all age groups against hepatitis A, while the combination vaccine only protects adults. The hepatitis vaccine is given in two doses. It is recommended that children get vaccinated at 12 to 23 months and again at 2 to 4 years. Adults who were not vaccinated as children can get vaccinated at any time so long as they get each dose 6 to 18 months apart. Some people should not get the hepatitis vaccine, such as those who are allergic to the vaccine ingredients and immune-compromised individuals. If you are sick, you should wait until you feel better to get the vaccine. The vaccine can also be given as post-exposure prophylaxis (after one contracts hepatitis A), to help fight the disease.
